20101229040110.000|20101229040112.000|TR0|
20101229040112.000|20101229040114.000|TR0|Chaos at the airport as this week's 
20101229040114.000|20101229040116.000|TR0|monster blizzard leaves airline passengers 
20101229040116.000|20101229040118.000|TR0|stranded on the tarmac for hours on end.  
20101229040118.000|20101229040121.000|TR0|It's every traveler's worst nightmare: no 
20101229040121.000|20101229040123.000|TR0|food, no water, screaming babies, and 
20101229040123.000|20101229040125.000|TR0|frustrated passengers breaking down in 
20101229040125.000|20101229040127.000|TR0|tears -- not just on one flight, but four, 
20101229040127.000|20101229040129.000|TR0|all at New York's John F. Kennedy 
20101229040129.000|20101229040132.000|TR0|International Airport, all without gates 
20101229040132.000|20101229040134.000|TR0|to let their passengers off the plane.  
20101229040134.000|20101229040136.000|TR0|Two Cathay Pacific flights, one stranded 
20101229040136.000|20101229040138.000|TR0|for a punishing 11 hours; a British 
20101229040138.000|20101229040140.000|TR0|Airways flight stranded seven hours; and 
20101229040140.000|20101229040142.000|TR0|an Aeromexico flight stuck for six hours.
20101229040142.000|20101229040145.000|TR0|
20101229040145.000|20101229040147.000|TR0|Why?  No one seems to know, but everyone 
20101229040147.000|20101229040149.000|TR0|is pointing fingers.  The New York/New 
20101229040149.000|20101229040151.000|TR0|Jersey Port Authority oversees Kennedy, 
20101229040151.000|20101229040153.000|TR0|which is a major hub for air travelers 
20101229040153.000|20101229040155.000|TR0|from around the country and the world.  
20101229040155.000|20101229040158.000|TR0|The Port Authority claims the airlines are 
20101229040158.000|20101229040200.000|TR0|to blame.
20101229040200.000|20101229040202.000|TR0|
20101229040202.000|20101229040204.000|TR0|Quote: "The reason for the delay is 
20101229040204.000|20101229040206.000|TR0|because the airlines brought in the planes 
20101229040206.000|20101229040209.000|TR0|without checking with terminal operations 
20101229040209.000|20101229040211.000|TR0|to see if there was a place to put them.  
20101229040211.000|20101229040213.000|TR0|It is an airline's responsibility to 
20101229040213.000|20101229040215.000|TR0|contact the terminal before bringing in 
20101229040215.000|20101229040217.000|TR0|flights, and they did not."
20101229040217.000|20101229040219.000|TR0|
20101229040219.000|20101229040222.000|TR0|But Cathay Pacific isn't buying it.  Its 
20101229040222.000|20101229040224.000|TR0|spokesperson says, the airline's intention 
20101229040224.000|20101229040226.000|TR0|was -- quote -- "to get passengers to New 
20101229040226.000|20101229040228.000|TR0|York as quickly as possible, and we 
20101229040228.000|20101229040230.000|TR0|anticipated to have gate space available." 
20101229040230.000|20101229040233.000|TR0|So, if it's not the airline or the 
20101229040233.000|20101229040235.000|TR0|airport's fault, who is it?  Try U.S. 
20101229040235.000|20101229040237.000|TR0|customs.  Noting that each of the stranded 
20101229040237.000|20101229040239.000|TR0|planes was an international flight, the 
20101229040239.000|20101229040241.000|TR0|Port Authority also suggests that, on the 
20101229040241.000|20101229040243.000|TR0|midnight shift, there may have been too 
20101229040243.000|20101229040246.000|TR0|few officers on duty to clear the 
20101229040246.000|20101229040248.000|TR0|passengers through customs.
20101229040248.000|20101229040250.000|TR0|
20101229040250.000|20101229040252.000|TR0|Of course, a customs spokesperson insists 
20101229040252.000|20101229040254.000|TR0|that it wasn't them, a spokesperson 
20101229040254.000|20101229040257.000|TR0|saying, "At no point were customs 
20101229040257.000|20101229040259.000|TR0|officials sent home," he said.  "For 
20101229040259.000|20101229040301.000|TR0|flights arriving after midnight, there is 
20101229040301.000|20101229040303.000|TR0|usually one terminal available, which is 
20101229040303.000|20101229040305.000|TR0|always staffed with customs officers."
20101229040305.000|20101229040307.000|TR0|
20101229040307.000|20101229040310.000|TR0|Whatever the cause, what about that 
20101229040310.000|20101229040312.000|TR0|airline passenger bill of rights that's 
20101229040312.000|20101229040314.000|TR0|supposed to limit how much time passengers 
20101229040314.000|20101229040316.000|TR0|can sit on a tarmac? Well, it turns out 
20101229040316.000|20101229040318.000|TR0|there are exceptions.  The rules don't 
20101229040318.000|20101229040321.000|TR0|apply if air traffic control determines 
20101229040321.000|20101229040323.000|TR0|there are safety or security reasons 
20101229040323.000|20101229040325.000|TR0|passengers should stay on the plane.
20101229040325.000|20101229040327.000|TR0|
20101229040327.000|20101229040329.000|TR0|And if the flight is operated by an 
20101229040329.000|20101229040331.000|TR0|international carrier, the rules don't 
20101229040331.000|20101229040334.000|TR0|apply at all.  But, right now, holiday 
20101229040334.000|20101229040336.000|TR0|travelers continue to suffer.

20101229041114.000|20101229041116.000|TR0|specific rules that need to be followed in 
20101229041116.000|20101229041118.000|TR0|delays on the tarmac, including food and

20101229041702.000|20101229041705.000|TR0|
20101229041705.000|20101229041707.000|TR0|Now, here's the background to this story 
20101229041707.000|20101229041709.000|TR0|and how it got to this point. Back in 
20101229041709.000|20101229041711.000|TR0|February, a month after the earthquake 
20101229041711.000|20101229041713.000|TR0|devastated Haiti, Waggoner, whose nickname 
20101229041713.000|20101229041715.000|TR0|is "Little Paul," was volunteering at a 
20101229041715.000|20101229041718.000|TR0|hospital when a man walked in with his 
20101229041718.000|20101229041720.000|TR0|deathly-ill son, who did not survive.
20101229041720.000|20101229041722.000|TR0|
20101229041722.000|20101229041724.000|TR0|The father, Frantz Philistin, was asked to 
20101229041724.000|20101229041726.000|TR0|return the following day to claim the 
20101229041726.000|20101229041729.000|TR0|body.  American doctor Kenneth Adams was 
20101229041729.000|20101229041731.000|TR0|present at the hospital the next day.  In 
20101229041731.000|20101229041733.000|TR0|an affidavit, Dr. Adams states that when 
20101229041733.000|20101229041735.000|TR0|Philistin was shown the remains of his son 
20101229041735.000|20101229041737.000|TR0|-- quote -- "The father jokingly said that 
20101229041737.000|20101229041739.000|TR0|it looked like the baby was still alive, 
20101229041739.000|20101229041742.000|TR0|but I pulled out my stethoscope and 
20101229041742.000|20101229041744.000|TR0|listened carefully for any breath sounds 
20101229041744.000|20101229041746.000|TR0|or heartbeat.  And there was none."
20101229041746.000|20101229041748.000|TR0|

20101229041755.000|20101229041757.000|TR0|official.  The boy's body was cremated by 
20101229041757.000|20101229041759.000|TR0|the hospital because Frantz Philistin said 
20101229041759.000|20101229041801.000|TR0|he had no money to bury his son.
20101229041801.000|20101229041803.000|TR0|
20101229041803.000|20101229041806.000|TR0|A colleague said that Waggoner's only role 
20101229041806.000|20101229041808.000|TR0|that day was being present with Mr. 
20101229041808.000|20101229041810.000|TR0|Philistin when he viewed his son's body.

20101229041845.000|20101229041847.000|TR0|me out of here?  I'm scared I will never

20101229041854.000|20101229041856.000|TR0|

20101229041858.000|20101229041900.000|TR0|it's been providing consular assistance to

20101229041922.000|20101229041924.000|TR0|KAYE:  How concerned are you about Paul's

20101229043855.000|20101229043857.000|TR0|year.  Tea Party favorite Christine 
20101229043857.000|20101229043859.000|TR0|O'Donnell made headlines first by knocking

20101229044536.000|20101229044538.000|TR0|DR. SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CORRESPONDENT 
20101229044538.000|20101229044540.000|TR0|(voice-over):  The speed can reach over 
20101229044540.000|20101229044542.000|TR0|190 miles an hour, the temperature inside 
20101229044542.000|20101229044544.000|TR0|the race car, 150 degrees.  Despite those 
20101229044544.000|20101229044547.000|TR0|extremes and the usual fire-spitting 
20101229044547.000|20101229044549.000|TR0|crashes, Jennifer Jo Cobb feels right at 
20101229044549.000|20101229044551.000|TR0|home on the NASCAR racetrack.
20101229044551.000|20101229044553.000|TR0|
20101229044553.000|20101229044555.000|TR0|This up-and-coming driver is paving the 
20101229044555.000|20101229044558.000|TR0|way for aspiring female racers and making 
20101229044558.000|20101229044600.000|TR0|quite a name for herself.
20101229044600.000|20101229044602.000|TR0|
20101229044602.000|20101229044604.000|TR0|Out of the 35 or so women who've made it 
20101229044604.000|20101229044606.000|TR0|into NASCAR's elite series, Jennifer's 
20101229044606.000|20101229044608.000|TR0|2010 finish was the best ever, winning her 
20101229044608.000|20101229044611.000|TR0|$250,000. Jennifer also owns her own team.
20101229044611.000|20101229044613.000|TR0|
20101229044613.000|20101229044615.000|TR0|Her love of NASCAR began as a little girl, 
20101229044615.000|20101229044617.000|TR0|watching her father, Joe Cobb, competing 
20101229044617.000|20101229044619.000|TR0|on the racetrack.  The 37-year-old has 
20101229044619.000|20101229044622.000|TR0|come very far since her first race in 1991 
20101229044622.000|20101229044624.000|TR0|in her hometown of Kansas City.  And she's 
20101229044624.000|20101229044626.000|TR0|already set her sights on the Daytona 500 
20101229044626.000|20101229044628.000|TR0|in 2012.
20101229044628.000|20101229044630.000|TR0|
20101229044630.000|20101229044632.000|TR0|(on camera):  So at 16 you're drag racing 
20101229044632.000|20101229044635.000|TR0|Trans Ams, is that right?
20101229044635.000|20101229044637.000|TR0|
20101229044637.000|20101229044639.000|TR0|JENNIFER JO COBB, NASCAR DRIVER:  Yes, it 
20101229044639.000|20101229044641.000|TR0|is.  Believe it or not.
20101229044641.000|20101229044643.000|TR0|
20101229044643.000|20101229044646.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Where does that come from?  You 
20101229044646.000|20101229044648.000|TR0|decide, I mean, a 16-year-old young lady 
20101229044648.000|20101229044650.000|TR0|decides to do that sort of thing.  What 
20101229044650.000|20101229044652.000|TR0|started that?
20101229044652.000|20101229044654.000|TR0|
20101229044654.000|20101229044656.000|TR0|COBB:  You know, I'm literally getting out 
20101229044656.000|20101229044659.000|TR0|of dance practice and then going and drag 
20101229044659.000|20101229044701.000|TR0|racing Trans Ams, so I lived kind of an 
20101229044701.000|20101229044703.000|TR0|ironic life, I think I always have.  But 
20101229044703.000|20101229044705.000|TR0|my dad has been a race-car driver since I 
20101229044705.000|20101229044707.000|TR0|was three years old, and in racing we say 
20101229044707.000|20101229044710.000|TR0|it's in your blood.
20101229044710.000|20101229044712.000|TR0|
20101229044712.000|20101229044714.000|TR0|And there's no denying that it's 
20101229044714.000|20101229044716.000|TR0|definitely in my blood, from both my 
20101229044716.000|20101229044718.000|TR0|father's side and my mom's cousin is who 
20101229044718.000|20101229044720.000|TR0|actually got my father started racing.
20101229044720.000|20101229044723.000|TR0|
20101229044723.000|20101229044725.000|TR0|GUPTA:  So they got you in dance lessons.  
20101229044725.000|20101229044727.000|TR0|You want to race cars. What propels you to 
20101229044727.000|20101229044729.000|TR0|do it, though?  I mean, in the blood, your 
20101229044729.000|20101229044731.000|TR0|father did this, but what propels you at 
20101229044731.000|20101229044733.000|TR0|that age to start thinking about something 
20101229044733.000|20101229044736.000|TR0|that's, A, usually for people who are 
20101229044736.000|20101229044738.000|TR0|older, and male?
20101229044738.000|20101229044740.000|TR0|
20101229044740.000|20101229044742.000|TR0|COBB:  You know, I think every child has a 
20101229044742.000|20101229044744.000|TR0|big dream, and at 3 years old my mom put 
20101229044744.000|20101229044747.000|TR0|me into dance classes.  And at 3 years old 
20101229044747.000|20101229044749.000|TR0|my dad started driving race cars.  And, 
20101229044749.000|20101229044751.000|TR0|you know, dance was wonderful, served a 
20101229044751.000|20101229044753.000|TR0|great purpose for my life, but I'm not 
20101229044753.000|20101229044755.000|TR0|going to grow up and be a ballerina.
20101229044755.000|20101229044757.000|TR0|
20101229044757.000|20101229044800.000|TR0|I feel like God planted a seed in my 
20101229044800.000|20101229044802.000|TR0|heart, and at 8 years old in my father's 
20101229044802.000|20101229044804.000|TR0|garage, I said, "I want to be a race car 
20101229044804.000|20101229044806.000|TR0|driver."
20101229044806.000|20101229044808.000|TR0|
20101229044808.000|20101229044811.000|TR0|And the reaction was, like, you know, 
20101229044811.000|20101229044813.000|TR0|rolling of the eyes and shaking of the 
20101229044813.000|20101229044815.000|TR0|head and, "OK, go along now." You know?  
20101229044815.000|20101229044817.000|TR0|"Go somewhere else. We're busy working on 
20101229044817.000|20101229044819.000|TR0|your dad's car for Friday nights."
20101229044819.000|20101229044821.000|TR0|
20101229044821.000|20101229044824.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Right.  Are you a competitive 
20101229044824.000|20101229044826.000|TR0|person?
20101229044826.000|20101229044828.000|TR0|
20101229044828.000|20101229044830.000|TR0|COBB:  I don't believe I'm overly 
20101229044830.000|20101229044832.000|TR0|competitive off of the racetrack.  I think 
20101229044832.000|20101229044835.000|TR0|I reserve everything that I have for on

20101229044837.000|20101229044839.000|TR0|
20101229044839.000|20101229044841.000|TR0|GUPTA:  And as far as the type of training 
20101229044841.000|20101229044843.000|TR0|to be a race car driver, I mean, you think 
20101229044843.000|20101229044845.000|TR0|about the physical demands, which I know,

20101229044852.000|20101229044854.000|TR0|challenging.  There are mental demands and

20101229044856.000|20101229044859.000|TR0|First of all, do you train for your events

20101229045808.000|20101229045810.000|TR0|they're also calling the response an epic 
20101229045810.000|20101229045812.000|TR0|fail.  That's one reason.
20101229045812.000|20101229045814.000|TR0|
20101229045814.000|20101229045817.000|TR0|The other is simpler: it is a New Yorker's 
20101229045817.000|20101229045819.000|TR0|God-given right to complain.  But not a 
20101229045819.000|20101229045821.000|TR0|mayor's right to complain about the 
20101229045821.000|20101229045823.000|TR0|complaining. Besides, he should have seen 
20101229045823.000|20101229045825.000|TR0|it coming.  He watches the news.
20101229045825.000|20101229045827.000|TR0|

20101229045830.000|20101229045832.000|TR0|
20101229045832.000|20101229045834.000|TR0|PETER FINCH, ACTOR:  I want you to get up 
20101229045834.000|20101229045836.000|TR0|right now and go to the window, open it

20101229045838.000|20101229045841.000|TR0|mad as hell and I'm not going to take this 
20101229045841.000|20101229045843.000|TR0|anymore."

20101229045847.000|20101229045849.000|TR0|
20101229045849.000|20101229045851.000|TR0|KAYE:  No, that was not the great Jack 
20101229045851.000|20101229045854.000|TR0|Cafferty but the great Peter Finch in the 
20101229045854.000|20101229045856.000|TR0|prophetic movie "Network" 34 years ago.
20101229045856.000|20101229045858.000|TR0|
20101229045858.000|20101229045900.000|TR0|So we're ignoring the prophecy, crunching 
20101229045900.000|20101229045902.000|TR0|the truck, and giving New Yorkers a reason 
20101229045902.000|20101229045905.000|TR0|to say they're mad as hell.  The mayor and 
20101229045905.000|20101229045907.000|TR0|the city earn a spot on the RidicuList.
20101229045907.000|20101229045909.000|TR0|
20101229045909.000|20101229045911.000|TR0|That -- that picture right there, by the 
20101229045911.000|20101229045913.000|TR0|way, is what the city is going to look 
20101229045913.000|20101229045915.000|TR0|like, sometime next June, if we're lucky.
